newsitem.title: NORWAY: Former Norwegian premier to seek top job at WHO.
newsitem.headline: Former Norwegian premier to seek top job at WHO.

text.p: Former Norwegian prime minister Gro Harlem Brundtland has agreed to stand as a candidate for the top job at the United Nations World Health Organisation (WHO), the Norwegian Foreign Ministry said on Sunday.

Brundtland, 57, a medical doctor by training, resigned as prime minister last October after dominating Norwegian politics for more than a decade. She subsequently declared she would also quit parliament this year.
"She has said 'yes' to be at the disposal (of the WHO) if there is broad support for her candidacy by the member countries of the WHO," Geir Pedersen, spokesman at the Foreign Ministry, told Reuters.
Pedersen said Brundtland had received requests from several WHO-members to give a positive signal to the agency's board and had now delivered her intention before the May deadline.
The national NTB news agency reported on Sunday that both Britain and the United States were among those who had asked her to stand as a candidate.

The three-time Norwegian premier has long been muted as a favourite to head the Geneva-based WHO although Brundtland herself has always refused to comment on speculation that she might leave Norway for an international position.

The leading international health institution has come under increasing criticism both from within and outside the agency for mismanagement. The authority is expected to announce in May, 1998 a new director general, who will take over from incumbent Dr Hiroshi Nakajima of Japan the following July.
Brundtland has enjoyed international recognition since 1983 as chairwoman of the U.N. World Commission on Environment and Development and is also known as a champion of women's issues.
